body: There's a lot missing from the docs, this kind of stuff included. A PR to expand the documentation would be much appreciated!

I'll see if I can get a PR at some point. For now, I'll use this comment to keep track of what's set on context here while I work with v4. (And in some cases what each does)
- `router` [[code]](https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/v4/modules/StaticRouter.js#L61-L64) - Used for directly manipulating the router instead of using `<Link>` `<Redirect>`.
- `history` [[code]](https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/v4/modules/History.js#L14) references the `history` library except on ServerRouter I think.
- `match` [[code]](https://github.com/ReactTraining/react-router/blob/v4/modules/MatchProvider.js#L35-L46) - Contains internals about what is currently 'matched'.

issue.title: No imperative router API documentation.
issue.body:
v4 Docs:  The router imperative API has no documentation. It also may bear mentioning to a user the bare bones of how context works since most new to intermediate React uses don't know it even exists or how to access it.

Is this something you'd like help with?

body: Added some initial docs in the linked PR #4194. There were some things I'm not sure about like the preventTransitions function, but it might do for a first pass.

rename.from: Documentation for router and history Context usage.

body:
Just wanted to chime in here and say that I'm not 100% completely satisfied with the signature of `context.router` in the current v4. `this.context.router.history` feels clunky, as does `this.context.router.getMatch()`. Since we're planning on exposing `this.context.router` as a first-class API (as we did in previous versions), I'd like to do a bit more bikeshedding here before we call it good and document it.

IMO, the best high-level API would be to have the router act exactly like a history object, but with an extra `match` property. So, for example:

```
context.router = {
  ...history,
  match: {
    params: ...,
    isExact: ...,
    path: ...,
    url: ...
  }
}
```

From an implementation perspective, this will be a little tricky because we're using subscriptions to communicate state changes down the hierarchy, so we'll need to update the actual router object in place. But I believe it's possible.

issue.title: Animating with <Switch> using previous pathname

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Used to close PRs that haven't gone through/been accepted the Proposal process yet

issue.body:
Animation with `<Switch>` is a little bit confusing. The goal is to animate the entering and leaving `<Route>`s, but what you have to do is animate the `<Switch>`. Unfortunately, when a `<Switch>` is rendered, it grabs the most current `history.location.pathname`. This means that both entering and exiting `<Switch>`es are choosing which `<Route>` to render based on the current location. I was able to get around that by adding a `pathname` prop to `<Switch>`, which will prefer that over grabbing the current `history.location.pathname`.

```js
const Routes = withRouter(({ history }) => (
  <CSSTransitionGroup
    transitionName='fade'
    transitionEnterTimeout={500}
    transitionLeaveTimeout={500}
    >
    <Switch key={history.location.pathname} pathname={history.location.pathname}>
      <Route path="/red" render={Red} />
      <Route path="/green" render={Green} />
      <Route path="/blue" render={Blue} />
    </Switch>
  </CSSTransitionGroup>
))
```

body: Added some docs in bce756033fcf06fc01565ed07cdbdf44edc98234. Please review and give me some feedback if you get a sec.
